lines.text: Enter SHALLOW, SLENDER, and SIR HUGH EVANS

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Sir Hugh, persuade me not; I will make a Star- chamber matter of it: if he were twenty Sir John Falstaffs, he shall not abuse Robert Shallow, esquire.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: In the county of Gloucester, justice of peace and 'Coram.'

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Ay, cousin Slender, and 'Custalourum.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: Ay, and 'Rato-lorum' too; and a gentleman born, master parson; who writes himself 'Armigero,' in any bill, warrant, quittance, or obligation, 'Armigero.'

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Ay, that I do; and have done any time these three hundred years.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: All his successors gone before him hath done't; and all his ancestors that come after him may: they may give the dozen white luces in their coat.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: It is an old coat.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: The dozen white louses do become an old coat well; it agrees well, passant; it is a familiar beast to man, and signifies love.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: The luce is the fresh fish; the salt fish is an old coat.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: I may quarter, coz.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: You may, by marrying.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: It is marring indeed, if he quarter it.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Not a whit.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Yes, py'r lady; if he has a quarter of your coat, there is but three skirts for yourself, in my simple conjectures: but that is all one. If Sir John Falstaff have committed disparagements unto you, I am of the church, and will be glad to do my benevolence to make atonements and compremises between you.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: The council shall bear it; it is a riot.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: It is not meet the council hear a riot; there is no fear of Got in a riot: the council, look you, shall desire to hear the fear of Got, and not to hear a riot; take your vizaments in that.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Ha! o' my life, if I were young again, the sword should end it.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: It is petter that friends is the sword, and end it: and there is also another device in my prain, which peradventure prings goot discretions with it: there is Anne Page, which is daughter to Master Thomas Page, which is pretty virginity.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: Mistress Anne Page? She has brown hair, and speaks small like a woman.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: It is that fery person for all the orld, as just as you will desire; and seven hundred pounds of moneys, and gold and silver, is her grandsire upon his death's-bed--Got deliver to a joyful resurrections! --give, when she is able to overtake seventeen years old: it were a goot motion if we leave our pribbles and prabbles, and desire a marriage between Master Abraham and Mistress Anne Page.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: Did her grandsire leave her seven hundred pound?

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Ay, and her father is make her a petter penny.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: I know the young gentlewoman; she has good gifts.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Seven hundred pounds and possibilities is goot gifts.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Well, let us see honest Master Page. Is Falstaff there?

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Shall I tell you a lie? I do despise a liar as I do despise one that is false, or as I despise one that is not true. The knight, Sir John, is there; and, I beseech you, be ruled by your well-willers. I will peat the door for Master Page. What, hoa! Got pless your house here!
Knocks

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: [Within]  Who's there?
Enter PAGE

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Here is Got's plessing, and your friend, and Justice Shallow; and here young Master Slender, that peradventures shall tell you another tale, if matters grow to your likings.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: I am glad to see your worships well. I thank you for my venison, Master Shallow.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Master Page, I am glad to see you: much good do it your good heart! I wished your venison better; it was ill killed. How doth good Mistress Page?--and I thank you always with my heart, la! with my heart.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Sir, I thank you.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Sir, I thank you; by yea and no, I do.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: I am glad to see you, good Master Slender.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: How does your fallow greyhound, sir? I heard say he was outrun on Cotsall.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: It could not be judged, sir.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: You'll not confess, you'll not confess.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: That he will not. 'Tis your fault, 'tis your fault; 'tis a good dog.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: A cur, sir.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Sir, he's a good dog, and a fair dog: can there be more said? he is good and fair. Is Sir John Falstaff here?

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Sir, he is within; and I would I could do a good office between you.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: It is spoke as a Christians ought to speak.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: He hath wronged me, Master Page.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Sir, he doth in some sort confess it.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: If it be confessed, it is not redress'd: is not that so, Master Page? He hath wronged me; indeed he hath, at a word, he hath, believe me: Robert Shallow, esquire, saith, he is wronged.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Here comes Sir John.
Enter FALSTAFF, BARDOLPH, NYM, and PISTOL

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Now, Master Shallow, you'll complain of me to the king?

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Knight, you have beaten my men, killed my deer, and broke open my lodge.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: But not kissed your keeper's daughter?

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Tut, a pin! this shall be answered.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: I will answer it straight; I have done all this. That is now answered.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: The council shall know this.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: 'Twere better for you if it were known in counsel: you'll be laughed at.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Pauca verba, Sir John; goot worts.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Good worts! good cabbage. Slender, I broke your head: what matter have you against me?

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: Marry, sir, I have matter in my head against you; and against your cony-catching rascals, Bardolph, Nym, and Pistol.

lines.speaker: bardolph
lines.text: You Banbury cheese!

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: Ay, it is no matter.

lines.speaker: pistol
lines.text: How now, Mephostophilus!

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: Ay, it is no matter.

lines.speaker: nym
lines.text: Slice, I say! pauca, pauca: slice! that's my humour.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: Where's Simple, my man? Can you tell, cousin?

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Peace, I pray you. Now let us understand. There is three umpires in this matter, as I understand; that is, Master Page, fidelicet Master Page; and there is myself, fidelicet myself; and the three party is, lastly and finally, mine host of the Garter.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: We three, to hear it and end it between them.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Fery goot: I will make a prief of it in my note- book; and we will afterwards ork upon the cause with as great discreetly as we can.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Pistol!

lines.speaker: pistol
lines.text: He hears with ears.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: The tevil and his tam! what phrase is this, 'He hears with ear'? why, it is affectations.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Pistol, did you pick Master Slender's purse?

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: Ay, by these gloves, did he, or I would I might never come in mine own great chamber again else, of seven groats in mill-sixpences, and two Edward shovel-boards, that cost me two shilling and two pence apiece of Yead Miller, by these gloves.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Is this true, Pistol?

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: No; it is false, if it is a pick-purse.

lines.speaker: pistol
lines.text: Ha, thou mountain-foreigner! Sir John and Master mine, I combat challenge of this latten bilbo. Word of denial in thy labras here! Word of denial: froth and scum, thou liest!

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: By these gloves, then, 'twas he.

lines.speaker: nym
lines.text: Be avised, sir, and pass good humours: I will say 'marry trap' with you, if you run the nuthook's humour on me; that is the very note of it.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: By this hat, then, he in the red face had it; for though I cannot remember what I did when you made me drunk, yet I am not altogether an ass.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: What say you, Scarlet and John?

lines.speaker: bardolph
lines.text: Why, sir, for my part I say the gentleman had drunk himself out of his five sentences.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: It is his five senses: fie, what the ignorance is!

lines.speaker: bardolph
lines.text: And being fap, sir, was, as they say, cashiered; and so conclusions passed the careires.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: Ay, you spake in Latin then too; but 'tis no matter: I'll ne'er be drunk whilst I live again, but in honest, civil, godly company, for this trick: if I be drunk, I'll be drunk with those that have the fear of God, and not with drunken knaves.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: So Got udge me, that is a virtuous mind.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: You hear all these matters denied, gentlemen; you hear it. Enter ANNE PAGE, with wine; MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE, following

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Nay, daughter, carry the wine in; we'll drink within.
Exit ANNE PAGE

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: O heaven! this is Mistress Anne Page.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: How now, Mistress Ford!

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Mistress Ford, by my troth, you are very well met: by your leave, good mistress.
Kisses her

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Wife, bid these gentlemen welcome. Come, we have a hot venison pasty to dinner: come, gentlemen, I hope we shall drink down all unkindness.
Exeunt all except SHALLOW, SLENDER, and SIR HUGH EVANS

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: I had rather than forty shillings I had my Book of Songs and Sonnets here. How now, Simple! where have you been? I must wait on myself, must I? You have not the Book of Riddles about you, have you?
Enter SIMPLE

lines.speaker: simple
lines.text: Book of Riddles! why, did you not lend it to Alice Shortcake upon All-hallowmas last, a fortnight afore Michaelmas?

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Come, coz; come, coz; we stay for you. A word with you, coz; marry, this, coz: there is, as 'twere, a tender, a kind of tender, made afar off by Sir Hugh here. Do you understand me?

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: Ay, sir, you shall find me reasonable; if it be so, I shall do that that is reason.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Nay, but understand me.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: So I do, sir.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Give ear to his motions, Master Slender: I will description the matter to you, if you be capacity of it.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: Nay, I will do as my cousin Shallow says: I pray you, pardon me; he's a justice of peace in his country, simple though I stand here.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: But that is not the question: the question is concerning your marriage.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Ay, there's the point, sir.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Marry, is it; the very point of it; to Mistress Anne Page.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: Why, if it be so, I will marry her upon any reasonable demands.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: But can you affection the 'oman? Let us command to know that of your mouth or of your lips; for divers philosophers hold that the lips is parcel of the mouth. Therefore, precisely, can you carry your good will to the maid?

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Cousin Abraham Slender, can you love her?

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: I hope, sir, I will do as it shall become one that would do reason.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Nay, Got's lords and his ladies! you must speak possitable, if you can carry her your desires towards her.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: That you must. Will you, upon good dowry, marry her?

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: I will do a greater thing than that, upon your request, cousin, in any reason.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Nay, conceive me, conceive me, sweet coz: what I do is to pleasure you, coz. Can you love the maid?

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: I will marry her, sir, at your request: but if there be no great love in the beginning, yet heaven may decrease it upon better acquaintance, when we are married and have more occasion to know one another; I hope, upon familiarity will grow more contempt: but if you say, 'Marry her,' I will marry her; that I am freely dissolved, and dissolutely.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: It is a fery discretion answer; save the fall is in the ort 'dissolutely:' the ort is, according to our meaning, 'resolutely:' his meaning is good.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Ay, I think my cousin meant well.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: Ay, or else I would I might be hanged, la!

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Here comes fair Mistress Anne. Would I were young for your sake, Mistress Anne!
Re-enter ANNE PAGE

lines.speaker: anne page
lines.text: The dinner is on the table; my father desires your worships' company.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: I will wait on him, fair Mistress Anne.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Od's plessed will! I will not be absence at the grace.
Exeunt SHALLOW and SIR HUGH EVANS

lines.speaker: anne page
lines.text: Will't please your worship to come in, sir?

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: No, I thank you, forsooth, heartily; I am very well.

lines.speaker: anne page
lines.text: The dinner attends you, sir.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: I am not a-hungry, I thank you, forsooth. Go, sirrah, for all you are my man, go wait upon my cousin Shallow. A justice of peace sometimes may be beholding to his friend for a man. I keep but three men and a boy yet, till my mother be dead: but what though? Yet I live like a poor gentleman born.
Exit SIMPLE

lines.speaker: anne page
lines.text: I may not go in without your worship: they will not sit till you come.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: I' faith, I'll eat nothing; I thank you as much as though I did.

lines.speaker: anne page
lines.text: I pray you, sir, walk in.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: I had rather walk here, I thank you. I bruised my shin th' other day with playing at sword and dagger with a master of fence; three veneys for a dish of stewed prunes; and, by my troth, I cannot abide the smell of hot meat since. Why do your dogs bark so? be there bears i' the town?

lines.speaker: anne page
lines.text: I think there are, sir; I heard them talked of.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: I love the sport well but I shall as soon quarrel at it as any man in England. You are afraid, if you see the bear loose, are you not?

lines.speaker: anne page
lines.text: Ay, indeed, sir.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: That's meat and drink to me, now. I have seen Sackerson loose twenty times, and have taken him by the chain; but, I warrant you, the women have so cried and shrieked at it, that it passed: but women, indeed, cannot abide 'em; they are very ill-favored rough things.
Re-enter PAGE

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Come, gentle Master Slender, come; we stay for you.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: I'll eat nothing, I thank you, sir.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: By cock and pie, you shall not choose, sir! come, come.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: Nay, pray you, lead the way.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Come on, sir.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: Mistress Anne, yourself shall go first.

lines.speaker: anne page
lines.text: Not I, sir; pray you, keep on.

lines.speaker: slender
lines.text: I'll rather be unmannerly than troublesome. You do yourself wrong, indeed, la!
Exeunt
